NOTE the actual execution of this Commandment devolved upon the Priests (Mishneh Torah, Abodah, Hilchoth Kle Ha-Mikdash III,5), and it was binding only during the existence of the Sanctuary, and within the Land of Israel(Sefer Ha-Chinuch, Comm. 384).

title: Offering cattle of a minimum age
text: By this injunction we are commanded that any cattle we bring as an offering is to be eight days old or more, and not less. This is the Commandment [concerning an offering] whose time [for being acceptable] has not yet come because of [something inherent in] itself, and it is contained in His words(exalted be He), Then it shall be seven days under the dam(Lev. 22:27). This Commandment is also given in another form, viz: Seven days it shall be with its dam(Ex.22:30). It applies to all offerings of all kinds, private and public. From the words, But from the eighth day and thenceforth it may be accepted for an offering made by fire unto the Lord(Lev.22:27), we conclude that before then it would not be acceptable. Thus it is clearly forbidden to offer an animal which has not reached the age of acceptability; but as this is a Negative Commandment derived from a Positive Commandment(see Pos.Comm.4), the penalty of whipping is not incurred for its transgression, and he who brings (an offering) whose time has not come is not whipped, as explained in the chapter 'It and its Young', where it also says: 'Leave alone [the prohibition of bringing an offering] whose time has not yet come, for Scripture has juxtaposed it to a Positive Commandment, [and therefore there is no whipping for transgression it]. The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the Sifre, and at the end of Tractate Zabahim. NOTE in speaking of the object of this Commandment Maimonides says, 'This is the reason why no animal could be brought that was not yet seven days old: it is imperfet and repulsive, like an untimely birth' (Moreh Nebuchim, III,46)

title: Offering only unblemished sacrifices
text: By this injunction we are commanded that everything we offer [unto the Lord] is to be perfect in its kind, free from all blemishes mentioned in Scripture and from all [imperfections regarded as] blemishes by Tradition(See Maimonides' reference to 'Tradition' in note to Pos Comm 174 for a definition of the term). This injunction is contained in His words (exalted be He), It shall be perfect to be accepted(Lev. 22:21), on which the Sifra says: 'It shall be perfect to be accepted: this is a Positive Commandment(Sifra, see also Neg Comms 91-96). The words, '[Beside the continual burnt-offering...ye shall offer them] - they shall be unto you without blemish - and their drink-offerings'(Num 28:31), have been quoted as proof that the wines of drink-offerings and their oils and fine flour must be absolutely perfect and free from any flaw whatsoever. The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the eighth chapter of Menahoth. NOTE but the same rule should be observed in regard to every offering we make to the Lord: it must be of the highest excellence and of the very best. The house of prayer one builds must surpass his own dwelling-house; the hungry should be fed of the best and daintiest foods on one's table; the naked should be clothed with the very finest of one's garments, and one should dedicate [to the Lord] only of the best that he possesses - even as Scripture declares, All the fat is the Lord's (Lev 3:16; Mishneh Torah Abodah, Hilchoth Issure Mizbeach VII,II).

title: Salt being brought with every offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded to offer salt with every offering. It is contained in His words(exalted be He), With all thine offerings thou shalt offer salt(Lev. 2:13, see also Neg.Comm. 99). The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the Sifre and in Menahoth.

title: The Burnt-offering
text: By this injunction we were commanded as to the procedure in connection with the Burnt-offering; that is to say, that any Burnt-offering, whether it be a private or a public sacrifice, must be offered in such-and-such manner. This Commandment is contained in His words in Leviticus, When any man of you bringeth and offering unto the Lord,...if his offering be a burnt-offering of the herd, etc(Lev. 1:2-3). NOTE Scripture nowhere indicates the nature of the sin that necessitated the bringing of a Burnt-offering. According to the Sages, such an offering atones for sinful thoughts(Menahoth, Tosephta X,12), and for the violation of a Positive Commandment(Lev. 1:4, Sifra).

title: The Sin-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded that the Sin-offering, whatever it might be, must be offered in the manner specified [by Scripture]. This injunction is contained in His words (exalted be He), This is the law of the sin-offering, etc.(Lev.6:18). It is likewise explained in Leviticus how it is to be offered, what part of it is to burnt, and what part is to be eaten.(Lev. 7:3-7). NOTE the Sin-offering, and the Guilt-offering were considered as the Most Holy Things, whole the Peace-offering, the Thank-offering, and Firstling, the Tithe of Cattle, and the Passover-offering were regarded as the Lesser Holy Things. The former, in so far as they were consumed, had to be consumed within the Sanctuary Court, whole the Lesser Holy Things might be eaten anywhere in Jerusalem.

title: The Guilt-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded that the Guilt-offering must be offered in the manner specified [by Scripture]. This Commandment is contained in His words (exalted be He) in Leviticus: This is the law if the guilt-offering, etc(Lev. 7:1). Scripture explains how it is to be offered, what part of it is be burnt, and what part is to be eaten(Lev. 7:3-7). NOTE this type of offering could be brought by an individual only; there was no public Guilt-offering of any kind.

title: The Peace-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded that the Peace-offering must be offered in the manner specified in His words, If hi offering be a sacrifice of peace-offering, etc(Lev. 3:1), which are completed by the further words: This is the law of the Sacrifice of peace-offering...If he offer it for a thanksgiving, etc(Lev 7:11-12. This was known as the Thank-offering). These four rituals - to wit, those of the Burnt-offering, the Sin-offering, the Guilt-offering, and the Peace-offering - make up the whole of the ritual of sacrifices; for all offerings of animals, whether brought by an individual or by the congregation -of Israel], belong to one of these four kinds, except that the Guilt-offering is always an individual offering, as we have explained many times. Tractate Zabahim likewise contains the provisions of these four Commandments, and related matters associated with them, showing what rites are obligatory [in offering a sacrifice], what may not be done without breach of the law, what makes [a sacrifice] invalid, and what procedure is correct. NOTE the Thank-offering was brought by an individual when delivered from sickness or imprisonment, as well as after having successfully completed a voyage either across the sea or through the wilderness (Ber. 54b)(Cg Note to Pos.Comm 19)

title: The Meal-offering`
text: By this injunction we are commanded that the Meal-offering must be offered in the manner specified [by Scripture] in respect of each of its various kinds. This injunction is contained in His words, When any one bringeth a meal-offering unto the Lord, etc.(Lev. 2:1); If thy offering be a meal-offering baked on a griddle, etc.(Lev. 2:5); If they offering be a meal-offering of the stewing-pan, etc.(Lev. 2:7), which are completed by the further words, This is the law of the meal-offering,etc.(Lev. 6:7). The provisions of this Commandment, with its many aspects, are explained in the Tractate which deals specially with this matter, namely Menahoth.

title: Offering of a Court that has erred
text: By this injunction we are commanded that the Court is to offer a sacrifice if it gives a wrong decision. This injunction is contained in His words (exalted be He), If the whole congregation of Israel shall err, the thing being hid from the eyes of the assembly, etc.(Lev.4:13). The provisions and conditions of this Commandment are fully explained in Tractate Horayoth and in several places in Tractate Zebahim.

title: The Fixed Sin-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded that whenever an individual has sinned unintentionally he must offer a Sin-offering. It is contained in His words(exalted be He), If any one of the common people, sin through error, etc(Lev. 4:27). This [offering] is a Fixed Sin-offering, that is, a Sin-offering which must be of an animal. We have already explained that the sins which when committed incur the penalty of a Sin-offering are those for which the penalty is extinction when they are committed wilfully, provided that the sin involves violation of a Negative Commandment, and that there is some act connected with it, as explained at the beginning of [Tractate] Kerithoth(Thus, Blaspheming the Name, onvolving mere utterance and connected with no act, entails extinction if wilfully committed, but does not entail a Fixed Sin-offering if commited unintentionally. The provisions of this Commandment are explained in Tractates Horayoth and Kerithoth, and in several places in Shabbath, Shevuoth, and Zebahim.

title: The Suspensive Guilt-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded to offer a certain sacrifice in case of doubt about one of those major sins for which the penalty is extinction if committed wilfully, and a Fixed Sin-offering if committed unintentionally. This sacrifice is called a Suspensive guilt-offering. An example of a case of doubt which calls for a Suspensive Guilt-offering is the following. Suppose a person has before two pieces of fat, one being fat of the kidneys [which is Scripturally forbidden food], and the other fat of the heart [Scripturally permitted food]. He eats one of the two, and the other is eaten by another person or lost. A doubt then arises in his mind whether the piece he has eaten was the permitted or the forbidden one. In such a case he must offer a sacrifice because of the doubt that has arisen, so as to get atonement, and this is called a Suspensive Guilt-offering. If it is subsequently established that the piece he ate was the fat of the kidneys, it is conformed that he has sinned unintentionally, and he must offer a Fixed Sin-offering.(See Pos Comm 69). The verse relative to this offering is in the book of Leviticus: If any one sin, and do any of the things which the Lord hath commanded not to be done, though he know it not, yet he is guilty, and shall bear his iniquity. And he shall bring a ram without blemish out of the flock, according to the valuation, for a guilt-offering unto the priest; and the priest shall make atonement for him concerning the error which he committed, though he knew it not(Lev. 5:17-18), that is to say, because he did not know whether he had erred or not. This is what the Sages call [a Sin] Unwittingly Committed. The provisions of this Commandment are explained in Tractate Kerithoth.

title: The Unconditional Guilt-offering
text: By this injunction we are commanded that one who commits certain transgressions must offer a Guilt-offering, and would thus obtain forgiveness. This is called an Unconditional Guilt-offering. The transgressions for which this offering is required are: sacrilege, robbery, having connection with a betrothed bondwoman, and swearing falsely in a case of a deposit. Whoever commits sacrilege unintentionally, that is to say, whoever derives a perutah's(i.e.the smallest copper coin current in the days of the Sages) worth of advantage from anything belonging to the Sanctuary, whether of the Consecreted Things that pertain to the Temple treasury, or of those that pertain to the Altar; or whoever robs his fellow of the value of a perutah or more, and swears [falsely in the matter]; or whoever has connection with a betrothed bondwoman, whether unintentionally or wilfully - in all these cases he is under obligation to bring an offering for his sin - not a Sin-offering, but a Guilt-offering, and such an offering is called an Unconditional Guilt-offering. As regard sacrilege His words (exlated be He) are: [if any one commit a trespass], and sin through error, in the holy things of the Lord, then he shall bring his forfeit, etc(Lev 5:15). [As regards robbery and swearing falsely in a case of a deposit] His words are: [If any one sin...] and deal falsely with his neighbour in a matter of a deposit,...and swear to a lie,...he shall bring his forfeit unto the Lord, a ram without blemish, etc.(Lev. 5:21-22,25) [As regards having connection with a betrothed bondwoman] His words are, And whosoever lieth carnally with a woman, that is a bondmaid, designated for a man...he shall bring his forfeit,etc(Lev. 19:20-21). The detailed rules of these Commandments are explained in Tractate Kerithoth.

title: The Offering of Higher or Lower Value
text: By this injunction we are commanded to offer a Sacrifice of Higher or Lower Value for certain definite transgressions. The transgressions for which this sacrifice is required are: the defilement of the Sanctuary or its Hallowed Things, an Oath of Utterance(i.e. an oath binding one to perform or to refrain from an action which the Torah does not forbid, e.g.'I swear that I will eat this loaf',etc.), and a [false] Oath concerning Testimony. If one who has been made unclean by any of the primiary source of uncleanness (as we have explained in the introduction to the Order of Tohoroth) unintentionally enters the Sanctuary, which would involve defilement of the Sanctuary; if one unintentionally eats meat that is holy, which would involve defilement of its Hallowed Things; if one swears an Oath of Utterance and unintentionally fails to keep it; if one swears a false oath concerning testimony, either unintentionally or wilfully - in each of these cases he must offer what is called a Sacrifice of Higher or Lower Value. This Commandment is contained in His words(exalted be He), If any one sin, in that he heareth the voice of adjuration, [he being a witness...if he do not utter it, then he shall near his iniquity;] of if any one touch any unclean thing...it being hidden from him that he is unclean...and when he knoweth of it, be guilty; or if any one swear clearly with his lips(i.e.not merely in his heart),...and it be hid from him...and it shall be, when he shall be guilty [in one of these things...] and he shall bring his forfeit...and if his means suffice not[for a lamb,etc.](Lev. 5:1-11). This sacrifice is called a Sacrifice of Higher or Lower Value because it has not to be of one specified kind, but may vary in accordance with the means of the transgressor who has to offer it. The provisions of this Commandment also are explained in Tractates Kerithoth and Shevuoth.

title: Making confession
text: By this injunction we are commanded to make oral confession of the sins we have committed against the Lord(exalted be He) after we have repented of them. This is the form of confession: 'O God, I have sinned, I have committed iniquity, I have transgressed, and I have done thus and thus.' One must elaborate and ask forgiveness with all the eloquence at his command. You must know that even in the case of transgressions for which one is under obligation to offer one of the offerings specified above, for which the Lord has promised forgiveness to him who offers them, the offering alone without confession is not sufficient. This follows from His words(exlated be He), Speak unto the children of Israel: When a man or woman shall commit any sin that men commit...then they shall confess their sin which they have done(Num 5:6-7). Commenting on this verse, the Mechilta says: 'Sonceit says: he shall confess that wherein he hath sinned(Lev. 5:5), we infer that he must confess upon the sin which he has committed, that is, upon the sin-offering whilst it is still alive, not after it has been slaughtered. The verse does not tell us that the individual is to make confession for any [sin] except that of entering the Sanctuary [in a state of uncleanness].' For this verse, He shall confess that wherein he hath sinned, occurs in the Scriptural portion 'Va'yikra'(Lev. 1:1-5:26) with reference to the defiling of the Sanctuary and its Hallowed Things, and to [transgressions] which are mentioned together with these [i.e. and Oath of Testimony and an Oath of Utterance], as we have explained. This is why the Mecilta says that we can derive the obligation of making confession from that verse only in the case of one who has defiled the Sanctuary. 'Whence do you derive its application in the case of violation of any of the other Commandments? From the words of Scripture: Speak unto the children of Israel: [When a man or woman shall commit any sin that men commit, to commit a trespass against the Lord, and that soul be guilty;] then they shall confess[their sin which they have done.] Whence do you further [extend the obligation so as to make it apply to those Commandments whose transgression entails the penalty of] extinction or death [by the hand of Heaven]? From the words Their sin, that is, all their sins, extending the application [of confession] to Negative Commandments. Which they have done, extends the application to [violations of] the Positive Commandments(Found in Num.5:6-7, Sifra Zuta). The Michilta says in the same place: 'Any sin that men commit; this means violation of Commandments which involve relations with one's fellow men, [such as] theft, robbery, and speaking evil. To commit a trespass [against the Lord]: this includes false swearing and blaspheming. [And that soul] be guilty: this extends the obligation of making confession to all who incur the death-panalty [by judicial sentence].One might think that even those who are about to be put to death through false witnesses [must confess to the crimes of which they are falsely accused]; Scripture therefore says that soul be guilty: that is to say, the obligation of making confession is not compulsory upon one who knows that he has committed no transgression and that false testimony has been given against him.' Thus it has been explained to you that all kinds of sins, great or small, and even [the violation of] Positive Commandments, carry with them the obligation of making confession. Now since the Commandment, then they shall confess, is mentioned only in connection with the obligation of offering a sacrifice, the idea might occur to us that confession is not itself a separate obligation, but is only something incidental to the sacrifice. Hence [the Sages] were obliged to explain this in the Mechilta as follows: 'One might think that confession is necessary [only] when an offering is made: whence do we learn that it is necessary also when there is no offering? From the words of Scripture: Speak unto the children of Israel...then they shall confess. Still one may think that the obligation of making confession is binding only in the Land[of Israel]; whence do you infer[that it is binding] in the Diaspora also? From Scripture: And they shall confess their iniquity and the iniquity of their fathers(Lev. 26:40. the verse refers to a time when Israel would be dispersed). Thus did Daniel[who lived outside the Land of Israel] say, Unto Thee, O Lord, belongeth righteousness(Dan 9:7). Thus it has been made clear to you from all we have said that confession is itself a separate obligation, and is binding upon the transgressor for every sin that he commits, whether it be in the Land or outside it, whether he has made an offering or not. In any case he is bound to make confession, inaccordance with His words(exalted be He), then they shall confess their sin. The Sifre also says: 'And [Aaron shall] confess:(Lev. 16:21): this means oral confession.' The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the last chapter of [Tractate] Kippurim [i.e.Yoma]. NOTE repentance, however, must be sincere and wholehearted: 'If a man says, 'I will sin and repent, and sin again and repent', he will be given no chance to repent'(Yoma 85b).

title: Offering brought by a zav
text: By this injunction we are commanded that a zav [a man suffering a flux] must, when healed, bring an offering of 'two tutle-doves, or two young pigeons, the one for a burnt-offering and the other for a sin-offering'. This is the offering of the zav, whose atonement is not complete until he brings it. This injunction is contained in His words(exalted be He), When he that hath an issue is cleansed of his issue...on the eighth day he shall take to him two turtle-doves, etc.(Lev. 15:13-14).

title: Offering brought by a zavah
text: By this injunction we are commanded that a zavah[i.e. a woman suffering a flux outside her menstrual period] must, when healed, bring an offering of 'two turtle-doves, or tow young pigeons'. This is the offering of the zavah, whose atonement is not complete until she brings it. Now one may perhaps object and say: 'Since the offering of a zav is the same as the offering of a zavah, and you [in enumerating the 613 Commandments] take into account only the type of offering involved, and pay no regard to the type of transgressor - this being your practice in the case of the Sin-offering, the Unconditional Guilt-offering, the Suspensive Guilt-offering and the Sacrifice of Higher or Lower Value, where you count each one as a separate Commandment, without troubling about the variety of transgressions for any of which the sacrifice in question may be required - why do you not adopt the same practice here, and disregard the fact that there are different individuals from whom the same offering of a bird may be required [thus counting the Commandments laid on the zav and the zavah as one Commandment only?] One who argues thus must be informed that the offering of the man or the woman suffering a flux is not brought because of sin, but is obligatory in certain circumstances. If the nature of the flux were the same in men and in women, as it is in name, the one being called a zav, and the other a zavah, then it would be appropriate to count the two Commandments as one. But that is not in fact the case; for it is the emission of semen that makes a man liable for an offering, but if a woman has a sort of emmision of semen, she is not a zavah, and it is only a flux of blood that makes a woman liable for an offering, whereas a flux of blood does not make a man liable. The word 'flux' means only 'flowing out', and what flows out is not always the same thing. The Sages say explicitly: 'A man conveys uncleanness through semen, a woman through blood.'(Lev 15:3, Sifre) The law of a zav and a zavah is not analogous to the law of a male and a female leper. This is clearly proved by what is said in Kerithoth: 'There are four persons whose atonement remains incomplete [until after the offering prescribed in each instance has been brought; namely], a man and a woman with a flux, a woman after childbirth, and a leper.' You see that the zav and the zavah are counted as two, because the flux of a man is different from that of a woman, whereas the male and the female leper are not distinguished. The verse relating to the offering of a zavah is: But if she be cleansed of her issue...on the eight day she shall take unto her tow turtle-doves, or two young pigeons, etc(Lev 15:28-29).

title: The offering after childbirth
text: By this injunction we are commanded that a woman giving birth to a child must bring an offering; to wit, a lamb of the first year for a Burnt-offering, and a young pigeon, or a turtle-dove, for a Sin-offering. If she is poor, she may bring two turtle-doves, or two young pigeons: the one for a Burnt-offering, and the other for a Sin-offering. She also is one of those whose atonement is not complete until she has bought the offering, as He says (exalted be He): When the days of her purification are fulfilled for a son, or for a daughter, she shall bring a lamb of the firtst year for a burnt-offering, and a young pigeon, or a turtle-dove, for a sin-offering.(Lev 12:6).

title: Offering brought by a leper
text: By this injunction we are commanded that a leper when healed if his leprosy must bring an offering of three animals - a Burnt-offering, a Sin-offering, and a Guilt-offering - and a log of oil. If he is poor, he may bring a he-lamb for a Guilt-offering, and two tutle-doves, or two young pigeons for a Burnt-offering and a Sin-offering respectively.[The Leper] is the fourth of those whose atonement is not complete [until he brings his offering]. This Commandment is contained in His words (exalted be He), On the eight day he shall take two he-lambs without blemish, and one ewe-lamb of the first year without blemish.(Lev 15:10).

title: The Tithe of cattle
text: By this injunction we are commanded that we are to single out a tithe of the clean animals born to us every year, to offer its fat and blood [on the Altar], and to eat the rest in Jerusalem. This injunction is contained in His words (exalted be He), All the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passeth under the rod, the tenth shall be holy unto the Lord.(Lev 27:32). This is the Tithe of cattle. The provisions of this Commandment are explained in the last chapter of Bechoroth. It is explained there that this Commandment is also binding outside of the Land [of Israel] and after the destruction of the Sanctuary. This is the law laid down in the Torah. But lest it should be eaten [outside Jerusalem] although unblemished - since we have no Sanctuary - the Rabbis ordained that this Commandment should be binding only while the Temple stood, and that on the rebuilding of the Temple it should be binding both in and outside the Land. NOTE The Priest received no part of the tuthe of cattle. The fat and blood of the animal once offered upon the Altar, it belonged wholly to its owner, as in the case of the Passover-offering. If the animal developed a defect - whether before or after its being set aside as tithe - it could be sluaghtered and eaten anywhere. The duty to set aside this tithe rested equally upon the Priest, the Levite, and the Israelite.

title: Sanctifying the first-born
text: By this injunction we are commanded to sanctify fisrtlings, that is to say, to separate them and set them aside for that which is to be done with them in due course. It is contained in His words(exalted be He), Sanctify unto Me all the first-born...both of man and of beast.(Ex 13:2). The Torah explains that beast here means only cattle and sheep and [among unclean animals] asses.(Deut 15:19; Ex 13:13). This Commandment is repeated as regards the firstling of a clean animal [ and that is the Commandment under discussion] in His words (exalted be He), All the firstling males that are born of thy herd, etc.(Deut 15:19). This law of the firstling of a clean animal provides that it is to be given to the Priests, who are to offer its fat and blood [on the Altar], and eat what is left of its meat. The detailed rules of this Commandment are fully explained in Tractate Beechoroth.

title: Redeeming the first-born
text: BY this injunction we are commanded to redeem the human firstling, and to give the redemption money to a Priest. It is contained in his words (exalted be He), The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto me.(Ex 12:28). The manner of this 'giving' is thus explained: the first-born is redeemed from the Priest, who has as it were a title to him, and is brought from him for five selas. The Commandment is contained in His words(exalted be He).: howbeit, the first-born of man shalt thou surely redeem(Num 18:15), and this is the Commandment of the Redemption of this first-born son. This obligation is not binding upon woman: it is a duty incumbent upon a father in relation to his son, as explained in Kiddushin. All the provisions of this Commandment are explained as explained in Bechoroth.
